page.title: 09ECOLOGY IN NETHERBURY
page.content: No part of the area has escaped mankind's attention. The northeast l km. square is mainly a built up part of Beaminster. There are also two villages less densely populated within the block. There are two sizeable areas of woodland, one of 12 hectares of wood/parkland around Parnham and one of 15 hectares in a thin ribbon along the banks of a tributary of the river Brit. The rest is mainly farming land of small to moderate sized fields, with a tendency to enlargement in recent years. The northern half is at the end of the Dorset down chalk areas, but it is not typical as most of the fields have been ploughed in recent years. There is one conservation area being developed for the protection of owls. Pollution is low. The area is fairly well served with footpaths.
